April 22, 2001: Fiction
DREAMCATCHER, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $28.) In the woods of Maine, four
hunters who have been friends since boyhood encounter a disoriented stranger
and a dangerous creature from another world.
1ST TO DIE, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $26.95.) Four women -- a
homicide inspector, a medical examiner, an assistant district attorney and a
journalist -- search for a killer who is stalking newlyweds.
A PAINTED HOUSE, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) The experiences of
a 7-year-old boy whose parents live and work in the cotton fields of Arkansas.
THE VILLA, by Nora Roberts. (Putnam, $25.95.) A successful businesswoman is
torn between her professional rivalry with a vintner and her powerful attraction to
him.
SCARLET FEATHER, by Maeve Binchy. (Dutton, $25.95.) Tom Feather and
Cathy Scarlet, friends from cooking school, start a catering company in Dublin.
THE BONESETTER'S DAUGHTER, by Amy Tan. (Putnam, $25.95.) A Chinese-
American woman in San Francisco struggles to understand her family and herself.
THE SKIES OF PERN, by Anne McCaffrey. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $25.) A brand-
new danger threatens the beautiful world of Pern; the 13th book in a fantasy
series.
SLIGHTLY SHADY, by Amanda Quick. (Bantam, $23.95.) An enterprising
Englishwoman forms an alliance with a mysterious spy.
STICKS & SCONES, by Diane Mott Davidson. (Bantam, $23.95.) The professional
cook and amateur sleuth Goldy Schulz investigates a murder in Colorado.
POTSHOT, by Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $23.95.) Spenser is hired by an
Arizona woman to investigate the apparent murder of her husband by a local
gang.
THE MARK, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $22.99.) The eighth
volume of the "Left Behind" series, in which the forces of good battle the forces of
evil after the rapture of the saved.
A DAY LATE AND A DOLLAR SHORT, by Terry McMillan. (Viking, $25.95.) The
complicated lives of Viola Price and her estranged husband, who live in Las
Vegas, and their four grown children.
THE LAST TIME THEY MET, by Anita Shreve. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) Two writers
who once had a passionate affair meet years later at a literary festival.
THE TRIUMPH OF KATIE BYRNE, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday,
April 22, 2001
Non-Fiction
SEABISCUIT, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $24.95.) A biography of the
horse whose career culminated in a 1938 match race with War Admiral.
AMERICAN TERRORIST, by Lou Michel and Dan Herbeck. (ReganBooks/ Harper
Collins, $26.) Two reporters examine the Oklahoma City bombing and the life of
Timothy McVeigh.
ABSOLUTE POWER, by David Limbaugh. (Regnery, $27.95.) A lawyer's critical
evaluation of the Clinton-Reno Justice Department.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The author
tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
THE O'REILLY FACTOR, by Bill O'Reilly. (Broadway, $23.) The host of a cable
news program offers opinions on what's right with America and what's wrong with
it.
ICE BOUND, by Jerri Nielsen with Maryanne Vollers. (Talk Miramax/Hyperion,
$23.95.) A memoir by the doctor who was at the South Pole when she discovered
that she had breast cancer.
FAST FOOD NATION, by Eric Schlosser. (Houghton Mifflin, $25.) From California
subdivisions to the New Jersey Turnpike: a survey of "the dark side of the all-
American meal."
WALKING THE BIBLE, by Bruce Feiler. (Morrow, $26.) A 10,000-mile journey
retracing the story told in the Pentateuch.
LONGABERGER, by Dave Longaberger. (HarperBusiness, $25.) A posthumous
memoir by the man who created the Longaberger basket company.
AN HOUR BEFORE DAYLIGHT, by Jimmy Carter. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) The
former president recalls his Depression-era childhood on a Georgia farm.
IN HARM'S WAY, by Doug Stanton. (Holt, $25.) The sinking of the cruiser
Indianapolis in World War II and the story of its survivors.
THE DARWIN AWARDS, by Wendy Northcutt. (Dutton, $16.95.) Commemorating
those people whose spectacularly stupid behavior served to "improve our gene
pool" by removing them from it.
WRESTLEMANIA, by Basil V. DeVito Jr. with Joe Layden.
(ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $49.95.) A profusely illustrated history of the W.W.F.
event.
IN THE WAKE OF THE PLAGUE, by Norman F. Cantor. (Free Press, $25.) A
